chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: All right, everyone.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's get started.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So today is going to be the second lecture

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: on object-oriented programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just a quick recap of last time.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: On Monday, we were introduced to this idea

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of object-oriented programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we saw these things called abstract data types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these abstract data types we implemented

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: through Python classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they allowed us to create our own data types that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: abstracted a general object of our choosing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've used lists before, for example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But with abstract data types, we were

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: able to create objects that were of our own types.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We saw the coordinate example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then at the end of the class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we saw the fraction example.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So today, we're going to talk a little bit more

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about object-oriented programming in classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to see a few more examples.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to talk about a few other nuances of classes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: talk about information hiding and class variables.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then in the second half of the lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to talk about the idea of inheritance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we're going to use object-oriented programming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to simulate how real life works.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in real life, you have inheritance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And in object-oriented programming,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can also simulate that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK, so the first few slides are going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be a little bit of a recap, just

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to make sure that everyone's on the same page

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: before I introduce a couple of new concepts

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: related to classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So recall that in the last lecture,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we talked about writing code from two

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different perspectives.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The first was from someone who wanted to implement a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So implementing the class meant defining your own object type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you defined the object type when you define the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you decided what data attributes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you wanted to define your object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what data makes up the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: What is the object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In addition to data attributes, we also

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: saw these things called methods.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And methods were ways to tell someone

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how to use your data type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So what are ways that someone can interact with the data type?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's from the point of view of someone

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: who wants to write their own object type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're implementing a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The other perspective was to write code

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from the point of view of someone

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: who wanted to use a class that was already written.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this involved creating instances of objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're using the object type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Once you created instances of objects,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you're able to do operations on them.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're able to see what methods whoever implemented

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the class added.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then you can use those methods

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in order to do operations with your instances.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So just looking at the coordinate example

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we saw last time, a little bit more in detail

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: about what that meant.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we had a class definition of an object type,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which included deciding what the class name was.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the class name basically told Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what type of an object this was.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: In this case, we decided we wanted to name a coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We wanted to create a coordinate object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the type of this object was therefore

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to be a coordinate.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We defined the class in a sort of general way.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we needed a way to be able to access data attributes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of any instance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we used this self variable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the self variable was we used

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to refer to any instance, to the data attributes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of any instance in a sort of general way

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: without actually having a particular instance in mind.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So whenever we access data attributes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we would say something like self.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: To access a data attribute, you'd

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: access the attribute directly with self.x.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Or if you wanted to access a method,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you would say self.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the method name, for example, distance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And really, the bottom line of the class definition

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is that your class defines all of the data, so data attributes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and all of the methods that are going

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be common across all of the instances.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So any instance that you create of a particular object type,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that instance is going to have this exact same structure.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: The difference is that every instance's values

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to be different.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when you're creating instances of classes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can create more than one instance of the same class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we can create a coordinate object here using this syntax

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: right here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you say the type, and then whatever values it takes in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And you can create more than one coordinate object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Each coordinate object is going to have

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: different data attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Sorry, it's going to have different data attribute

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: values.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Every coordinate object is going to have an x value and a y

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But the x and y values among different instances

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to vary.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that's the difference between defining a class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and looking at a particular instance of class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So instances have the structure of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for a coordinate, all instances

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: have an x value and a y value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But the actual values are going to vary

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: between the different instances.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So ultimately, why do we want to use object-oriented programming?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So far, the examples that we've seen were numerical,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a coordinate, a fraction.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But using object-oriented programming,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you can create objects that mimic real life.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I wanted to create objects of an object that defined

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a cat and an object that defined a rabbit,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I could do that with object-oriented programming.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I would just have to decide, as a programmer, what data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and what methods I'd want to assign

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to these groups of objects.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So using object-oriented programming, each one of these

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is considered a different object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And as a different object, I can decide

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that a cat is going to have a name, an age, and maybe

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: a color associated with it.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And these three here on the right, each one of these rabbits

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is also an object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm going to decide that I'm going to represent a rabbit

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: by just an age and a color.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And with object-oriented programming,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: using these attributes, I can sort of

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: group these three objects together and these three

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: objects together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm grouping sets of objects that

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: are going to have the same attributes together.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And attributes, this is also a recap of last time,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: come in two forms, data attributes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and procedural attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the data attributes are basically things

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that define what the object is.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So how do you represent a cat as an object?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And it's up to you as a programmer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to decide how you want to do that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: For a coordinate, it was pretty straightforward.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You had an x and y value.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If we're representing something more abstract, like an animal,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: then maybe I would say, well, I'm

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to represent an animal by an age and a name.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So it's really up to you to decide

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how you want to represent what data attributes you want

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to represent your object with.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Procedural attributes were also known as methods.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the methods are essentially asking,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what can your object do?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So how can someone who wants to use your object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how can someone interact with it?

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So for a coordinate, we saw that you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: can find the distance between two coordinates,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: maybe form an abstract animal object,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you might have it make a sound by maybe printing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to the screen or something like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: OK.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: This slide's also a recap of how to create a class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: just to make sure everyone's on the same page

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: before we go on.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we defined a class using this class keyword,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and we said class, the name of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So now we're going to create a more abstract animal class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We're going to see in the second half of the lecture

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: what it means to put something else in the parentheses.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But for now, we say that an animal is an object in Python.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So that means it's going to have all of the properties

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that any other object in Python has.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And as we're creating this animal,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: we're going to define how to create

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: an instance of this class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we say def, and this init was the special method

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that told Python how to create an object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Inside the parentheses, remember, we have the self,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which is a variable that we use to refer

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to any instance of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We don't have a particular instance in mind.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We just want to be able to refer to any instance.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we use the self variable.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the second parameter here

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is going to represent what other data we use

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to initialize our object with.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So in this case, I'm going to say

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I'm going to initialize an animal object with an age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when I create an animal, I need to give it an age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Inside the init are any initializations

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that I want to make.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first thing is I'm going to assign an instance variable

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is going to be the data attribute age

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be whatever is passed in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I'm also making another assignment here

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where I'm assigning the data attribute name

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to be none originally.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Later on in the code, when I want

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to create an animal object, I say the class name.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then I pass it in whatever parameters it takes,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in this case, the age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And I'm assigning it to this instance here.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So now we have this class animal.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: We've done the first part here, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is to initialize the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we've told Python how to create an object of this type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: There's a few other methods here that I've implemented.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Next two we call getters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the two after that we call setters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And getters and setters are very commonly used

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: when implementing a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So getters essentially return the values

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of any of the data attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you look carefully, get age

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is just returning self.age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And get name just returns self.name.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So they're very simple methods.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Similarly, set age and set name, we're

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: going to see what this funny equal sign is doing here

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: in the next couple of slides.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But setters do a very similar thing

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: where they're going to set the data attributes to whatever's

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: passed in.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So those are getters and setters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And then the last thing down here is this str method.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And this str method is used to tell Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: how to print an object of this type animal.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if you didn't have this str method,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: if you remember from last lecture, what ends up happening

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is you're going to get some message when

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: you print your object that says this

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is an object of type animal at this memory location, which

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is very uninformative.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you implement this method here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: which tells Python how to print an object of this type.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the big point of this slide is

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you should be using getters and setters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: You should be implementing getters and setters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for your classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we're going to see in the next couple of slides why,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: exactly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But basically, they're going to prevent bugs

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from coming into play later on if someone decides

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to change the implementation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we saw how to.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the previous slide, this slide here,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: shows the implementation of the animal class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And here, we can see how we can create

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: an instance of this object.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So we can say a is equal to animal 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is going to create a new animal object with an age of 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And we can access the object through the variable a.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Dot notation, recall, is a way for you

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to access data attributes and methods of a class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you can say a.age later on in your program,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and that is allowed.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: It'll try to access the age data attribute

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: of this particular instance of the class a.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is going to give you 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: However, it's actually not recommended to access data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: attributes directly.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is the reason.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So you're going to see in the next slide

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the reason why we're going to use getters and setters.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Instead, you should use the getage getter method

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to get the age of the animal.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So this is going to return also 3.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So these are going to do the same thing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the reason why you'd want to use getters and setters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is this idea of information hiding.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the whole reason why we're using classes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and object-oriented programming is

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: so that you can abstract certain data from the user.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: One of the things you should be abstracting

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is these data attributes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Users shouldn't really need to know how a class is implemented.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They should just know how to use the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So consider the following case.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Let's say whoever wrote the animal class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: wants to change the implementation.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And they've decided they don't want to call the data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: attribute age anymore.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: They want to call it years.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So when they initialize an animal,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: they say self.years is equal to age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So an animal still gets initialized by its age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And the age gets passed into a data attribute named years.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Since I'm implementing this class,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I want to have a getter, which is going to return self.years.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So I'm not returning self.age anymore,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: because age is no longer the data attribute I'm using.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So with this new implementation, if someone

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: was using this implementation and was accessing age directly,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: as accessing the data attribute age directly,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: with this new implementation, they'd actually get an error.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Because this animal that they created using

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: my old implementation no longer has an attribute named age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And so Python's going to spit out an error saying no attribute

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: found or something like that.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: If they were using the getter a.getAge,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: the person who implemented the class

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: re-implemented getAge to work correctly with their new data

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: attribute years as opposed to age.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I was using the getter getAge,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: I wouldn't have run into the bug.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So things to remember, write getters and setters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: for your classes.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: And later on in your code, use getters and setters

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: to prevent bugs and to promote easy to maintain code.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So information hiding is great.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: But having said that, Python is actually not

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: very great at information hiding.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python allows you to do certain things

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that you should never be doing.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So the first we've just seen, so the first

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: is to access data attributes from outside of the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I were to say a.age, Python

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: allows me to do that without using a getter and setter.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: Python also allows you to write to data attributes

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: from outside the class.

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: So if I implemented the class animal assuming

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: that age was a number, an integer,

chunks.title: Lecture
chunks.text: and all of my methods work as long as age is an integer,

chunks.title: Lecture

text: The following content is provided under a Creative Commons license. Your support will help MIT OpenCourseWare continue to offer high quality educational resources for free. To make a donation or view additional materials from hundreds of MIT courses, visit MIT OpenCourseWare at ocw.mit.edu. All right, everyone. Let's get started. So today is going to be the second lecture on object-oriented programming. So just a quick recap of last time. On Monday, we were introduced to this idea of object-oriented programming. And we saw these things called abstract data types. And these abstract data types we implemented through Python classes. And they allowed us to create our own data types that abstracted a general object of our choosing. So we've used lists before, for example. But with abstract data types, we were able to create objects that were of our own types. We saw the coordinate example. And then at the end of the class, we saw the fraction example. So today, we're going to talk a little bit more about object-oriented programming in classes. We're going to see a few more examples. And we're going to talk about a few other nuances of classes, talk about information hiding and class variables. And then in the second half of the lecture, we're going to talk about the idea of inheritance. So we're going to use object-oriented programming to simulate how real life works. So in real life, you have inheritance. And in object-oriented programming, you can also simulate that. OK, so the first few slides are going to be a little bit of a recap, just to make sure that everyone's on the same page before I introduce a couple of new concepts related to classes. So recall that in the last lecture, we talked about writing code from two different perspectives. The first was from someone who wanted to implement a class. So implementing the class meant defining your own object type. So you defined the object type when you define the class. And then you decided what data attributes you wanted to define your object. So what data makes up the object? What is the object? In addition to data attributes, we also saw these things called methods. And methods were ways to tell someone how to use your data type. So what are ways that someone can interact with the data type? So that's from the point of view of someone who wants to write their own object type. So you're implementing a class. The other perspective was to write code from the point of view of someone who wanted to use a class that was already written. So this involved creating instances of objects. So you're using the object type. Once you created instances of objects, you're able to do operations on them. So you're able to see what methods whoever implemented the class added. And then you can use those methods in order to do operations with your instances. So just looking at the coordinate example we saw last time, a little bit more in detail about what that meant. So we had a class definition of an object type, which included deciding what the class name was. And the class name basically told Python what type of an object this was. In this case, we decided we wanted to name a coordinate. We wanted to create a coordinate object. And the type of this object was therefore going to be a coordinate. We defined the class in a sort of general way. So we needed a way to be able to access data attributes of any instance. So we used this self variable. And the self variable was we used to refer to any instance, to the data attributes of any instance in a sort of general way without actually having a particular instance in mind. So whenever we access data attributes, we would say something like self. To access a data attribute, you'd access the attribute directly with self.x. Or if you wanted to access a method, you would say self. And then the method name, for example, distance. And really, the bottom line of the class definition is that your class defines all of the data, so data attributes, and all of the methods that are going to be common across all of the instances. So any instance that you create of a particular object type, that instance is going to have this exact same structure. The difference is that every instance's values are going to be different. So when you're creating instances of classes, you can create more than one instance of the same class. So we can create a coordinate object here using this syntax right here. So you say the type, and then whatever values it takes in. And you can create more than one coordinate object. Each coordinate object is going to have different data attributes. Sorry, it's going to have different data attribute values. Every coordinate object is going to have an x value and a y value. But the x and y values among different instances are going to vary. So that's the difference between defining a class and looking at a particular instance of class. So instances have the structure of the class. So for a coordinate, all instances have an x value and a y value. But the actual values are going to vary between the different instances. So ultimately, why do we want to use object-oriented programming? So far, the examples that we've seen were numerical, a coordinate, a fraction. But using object-oriented programming, you can create objects that mimic real life. So if I wanted to create objects of an object that defined a cat and an object that defined a rabbit, I could do that with object-oriented programming. I would just have to decide, as a programmer, what data and what methods I'd want to assign to these groups of objects. So using object-oriented programming, each one of these is considered a different object. And as a different object, I can decide that a cat is going to have a name, an age, and maybe a color associated with it. And these three here on the right, each one of these rabbits is also an object. And I'm going to decide that I'm going to represent a rabbit by just an age and a color. And with object-oriented programming, using these attributes, I can sort of group these three objects together and these three objects together. OK? So I'm grouping sets of objects that are going to have the same attributes together. And attributes, this is also a recap of last time, come in two forms, data attributes and procedural attributes. So the data attributes are basically things that define what the object is. So how do you represent a cat as an object? And it's up to you as a programmer to decide how you want to do that. For a coordinate, it was pretty straightforward. You had an x and y value. If we're representing something more abstract, like an animal, then maybe I would say, well, I'm going to represent an animal by an age and a name. OK? So it's really up to you to decide how you want to represent what data attributes you want to represent your object with. Procedural attributes were also known as methods. And the methods are essentially asking, what can your object do? So how can someone who wants to use your object, how can someone interact with it? So for a coordinate, we saw that you can find the distance between two coordinates, maybe form an abstract animal object, you might have it make a sound by maybe printing to the screen or something like that. OK. This slide's also a recap of how to create a class, just to make sure everyone's on the same page before we go on. So we defined a class using this class keyword, and we said class, the name of the class. So now we're going to create a more abstract animal class. We're going to see in the second half of the lecture what it means to put something else in the parentheses. But for now, we say that an animal is an object in Python. So that means it's going to have all of the properties that any other object in Python has. And as we're creating this animal, we're going to define how to create an instance of this class. So we say def, and this init was the special method that told Python how to create an object. Inside the parentheses, remember, we have the self, which is a variable that we use to refer to any instance of the class. We don't have a particular instance in mind. We just want to be able to refer to any instance. So we use the self variable. And then the second parameter here is going to represent what other data we use to initialize our object with. So in this case, I'm going to say I'm going to initialize an animal object with an age. So when I create an animal, I need to give it an age. Inside the init are any initializations that I want to make. So the first thing is I'm going to assign an instance variable age. So this is going to be the data attribute age to be whatever is passed in. And then I'm also making another assignment here where I'm assigning the data attribute name to be none originally. Later on in the code, when I want to create an animal object, I say the class name. And then I pass it in whatever parameters it takes, in this case, the age. And I'm assigning it to this instance here. So now we have this class animal. We've done the first part here, which is to initialize the class. So we've told Python how to create an object of this type. There's a few other methods here that I've implemented. Next two we call getters. And the two after that we call setters. And getters and setters are very commonly used when implementing a class. So getters essentially return the values of any of the data attributes. So if you look carefully, get age is just returning self.age. And get name just returns self.name. So they're very simple methods. Similarly, set age and set name, we're going to see what this funny equal sign is doing here in the next couple of slides. But setters do a very similar thing where they're going to set the data attributes to whatever's passed in. So those are getters and setters. And then the last thing down here is this str method. And this str method is used to tell Python how to print an object of this type animal.
